sen.j: 御招霊（おしょうれい、おしょうらい）は、日本の盂蘭盆（うらぼん）の年中行事の一つ。
sen.e: Oshorei (written as 御招霊; also pronounced as oshorai) is one of the annual events for Urabon festival (a Festival of the Dead or Buddhist All Soul's Day, around the 15th of July or August, depending on local customs) of Japan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Oshorei (written as 御招霊; also pronounced as oshorai) is one of the annual events for the Japanese Urabon festival (a Festival of the Dead or Buddhist All Soul's Day, held around the 15th of July or August, depending on local customs).

Oshorei (written as 御招霊; also pronounced as oshorai) is one of the annual events for the Japanese Urabon festival (a Festival of the Dead or Buddhist All Soul's Day, held around the 15th of July or August, depending on local customs).

sen.j: お盆に先祖の霊があの世から帰ってくるとされるものを迎える、または招く迎え火の一つ。
sen.e: It is a kind of mukaebi (welcoming fire) which is lit to welcome ancestors' souls returning from the other world for Obon festival (same meaning as Urabon Festival).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It is a kind of mukaebi (welcoming fire) which is lit to welcome ancestors' souls returning from the other world for the Obon festival (another word for Urabon Festival).
It is a kind of mukaebi (welcoming fire) which is lit to welcome ancestors' souls returning from the other world for the Obon festival (another word for Urabon Festival).

sen.j: ごしょうらいやごしょうれいと呼んだり、お招霊とも書かれる。
sen.e: It is also called Goshorai or Goshorei, and sometimes written as お招霊.
It is also called Goshorai or Goshorei, and sometimes written as お招霊 (Oshorei).
It is also called Goshorai or Goshorei, and sometimes written as お招霊 (Oshorei).

sen.j: 先祖が帰ってくるのに道が暗いと困るので明かりを持って迎える意味を持っている。
sen.e: Oshorei is practiced to guide ancestors with the light in the dark way home.
Oshorei is practiced to help guide ancestors home with a light in the darkness.
Oshorei is practiced to help guide ancestors home with a light in the darkness.

sen.j: 迎え火に対して、お盆の後にあの世に戻って行く先祖の霊を送り出す送り火に相対するものである。
sen.e: Mukaebi is the opposite practice of Okuribi, which is lit to see ancestors' souls off to the other world after Obon festival.
sen.cmt: 原文が不自然なようです。「迎え火に対して」でなく「迎え火は」ととらえて訳出しました。
sen.e: Mukaebi is the opposite practice of Okuribi, which is lit to see ancestors' souls off to the other world after Obon festival.
Mukaebi is the opposite practice of Okuribi, which is lit to see ancestors' souls off to the other world after Obon festival.

sen.j: 旧暦の7月15日 (旧暦)のお盆前の13日に行われた行事。
sen.e: The event used to be held on July 13 (around present-day August) according to the old lunisolar calendar, before Obon Festival on July 15 (the old calendar).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: According to the old lunisolar calendar, the event used to be held on July 13th (around present-day August), before the Obon Festival on July 15th (old calendar).
According to the old lunar calendar, the event used to be held on July 13 (around present-day August), before the Obon Festival on July 15 (old calendar).

sen.j: 村落の数人の男子の青年がやっと持ち上げられる程の重さの大きな松明（たいまつ）をそれぞれが持ち、大きく振り回して練り歩くものである。
sen.e: Several young men of the village carried big, heavy Taimatsu torches which they just manage one by one, and paraded through the streets waving them.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Several young men from the village would carry large, heavy Taimatsu torches which they could just barely manage on their own, and paraded through the streets waving them.
Several young men from the village would carry large, heavy Taimatsu torches which they could just barely manage on their own, and parade through the streets waving them.

sen.j: 直径7-10センチ程の太さ、背丈の1.3-1.5倍程の長さの孟宗竹に藁（いなわら）や麦藁の束を縛り付け、火を付けて松明とする。
sen.e: The torch is made of Moso-chiku (Phyllostachys edulis) with a diameter of 7-10 cm and a length of 1.3-1.5 times longer than their height, to which a bundle of rice or wheat straw is bound as kindling.

The torch is made of Moso-chiku (Phyllostachys edulis) with a diameter of 7-10 cm and a length of 1.3-1.5 times longer than their height, to which a bundle of rice or wheat straw is bound as kindling.

The torch is made of Moso-chiku (Phyllostachys edulis) with a diameter of 7-10 cm and a length of 1.3-1.5 times longer than their height, to which a bundle of rice or wheat straw is bound as kindling.

sen.j: また火持ちを良くするために杉の葉なども混ぜることがある。
sen.e: Sometimes cedar or other leaves are added to make the fire last well.
Sometimes cedar or other leaves are added to make the fire last longer.
Sometimes cedar or other leaves are added to make the fire last longer.

sen.j: 松明の火の粉も飛び火の用心から川べりで行われたが、あの世である暗い彼岸から三途の川を渡ってこの世に帰ってくる川面を照らす道案内や目印の意味合いがある。
sen.e: The event which strews sparks from torches was held on a riverbank as a precaution against fire, and also as a guide or a landmark of this world by lighting up the surface of the river for those who were coming back from the dark higan, or the other world, across Sanzu-no-kawa (Sanzu River).

As the event would spread sparks from the torches, it was held on a riverbank as a precaution against fire; this also acted as a landmark to guide souls to this world by lighting up the surface of the river for those who were coming back from the dark higan, or the other world, across Sanzu-no-kawa (Sanzu River).

As the event would spread sparks from the torches, it was held on a riverbank as a precaution against fire; this also acted as a landmark to guide souls to this world by lighting up the surface of the river for those who were coming back from the dark higan, or the other world, across Sanzu-no-kawa (Sanzu River).

sen.j: 血気盛んな若者であり、松明を大きく振り回すのは自然の成り行きでもあるが、風を切って火の勢いを増したり、火が消えないように満身の力で振り回す。
sen.e: The exaggerated gestures of waving torch is not only coming from the nature of hot-blooded young men, but also attempt to increase the fire, or prevent it from going out, by waving it through the air with all their might.

The exaggerated gestures of waving the torches is not only from the nature of hot-blooded young men, but also from an attempt to increase the fire, or prevent it from going out, by waving it through the air with all their might.

The exaggerated gestures of waving the torches is not only from the nature of hot-blooded young men, but also from an attempt to increase the fire, or prevent it from going out, by waving it through the air with all their might.

sen.j: 大きな松明は燃え尽きるまで10-15分間ほどかかる。
sen.e: It takes the big torch 10-15 minutes to burn out.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It takes these big torches 10-15 minutes to burn out.
It takes these big torches 10-15 minutes to burn out.

sen.j: 若者の年に一度の大仕事でもある。
sen.e: This is a big once-a-year job for young men.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: This is a big once-a-year job for young men.
This is a big once-a-year job for young men.

sen.j: この迎え火を村落の男子の青年以外の者達は離れた場所から見て、皆で共に先祖の霊を招き迎えることとなる。
sen.e: By viewing this mukaebi from a distance, villagers other than young men also welcome ancestors' souls all together.
By viewing this mukaebi from a distance, the other villagers, aside from the young men, join in welcoming their ancestors' souls.
By viewing this mukaebi from a distance, the other villagers, aside from the young men, join in welcoming their ancestors' souls.

sen.j: また、地域によっては大きな松明の周りを小さな松明を持って廻り『御座れ（ござれ）、御座れ』」と叫び、祖先の霊を呼び寄せたとされる。
sen.e: In some regions, people circled around a big Taimatsu torch with a small Taimatsu in their hands, and shouted "Gozare (Please come back), gozare" to call ancestors' souls to them.
sen.cmt: 原文の」は不要と思われますので、訳では削除しました。
sen.e: In some regions, people circled around a big Taimatsu torch with smaller Taimatsu torches in their hands, and shouted "Gozare (Please come back), gozare" to call ancestors' souls to them.
In some regions, people circled around a big Taimatsu torch with smaller Taimatsu torches in their hands, and shouted "Gozare (Please come back), gozare" to call ancestors' souls to them.

sen.j: 他には盂蘭盆の年中行事とは別に、先祖や水子の御霊（みたま）を招き供養することなども御招霊（ごしょうれい）と呼ばれることもある。
sen.e: Besides the annual event for Urabon festival, some other events such as memorial services for goryo (or mitama: spirit of a deceased person) of ancestors or mizuko (aborted, stillborn or miscarried fetus; newborn baby) are also called Goshorei.
sen.cmt: 原文は「御霊信仰（御霊）を招き」を招きとなっておりましたが、文が不自然に思えます。Wikipediaで検索すると「御霊（みたま）を招き」となっていましたので、原文修正し訳出しました。
sen.e: Aside from this annual event for the Urabon festival, some other events such as memorial services for the goryo (or mitama: spirit of a deceased person) of ancestors or mizuko (aborted, stillborn or miscarried fetus; newborn baby) are also called Goshorei.

Aside from this annual event for the Urabon festival, some other events such as memorial services for the goryo (or mitama: spirit of a deceased person) of ancestors or mizuko (aborted, stillborn or miscarried fetus; newborn baby) are also called Goshorei.

sen.j: お盆において、先祖を迎えるこの御招霊の迎え火と再びあの世に帰る際の送り火のいずれかが行われる事が多い。
sen.e: In many cases, only one of the two ceremonial fires is lit at Obon festival: mukaebi as oshorei, for welcoming ancestors, or okuribi for seeing off them.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In many cases, only one of the two ceremonial fires is lit at Obon festival: mukaebi as oshorei, for welcoming ancestors, or okuribi for seeing them off.
In many cases, only one of the two ceremonial fires is lit at Obon festival: mukaebi as oshorei, for welcoming ancestors, or okuribi for seeing them off.

sen.j: 両者とも行うとされることはあまり見当たらない。
sen.e: It rarely happens that both of them are practiced.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It rarely happens that both events are practiced.
It rarely happens that both events are practiced.

sen.j: 送り火が家庭の玄関先や庭で行われるものから京都の五山送り火など大規模なものまで現在も行事として行われる。
sen.e: As for okuribi, it is still observed today at the entrance or in the garden of a house, and also in larger scale such as Gozan Okuribi (Bonfire Events on Five Mountains) in Kyoto.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: As for okuribi, it is still observed today at the entrance or in the garden of some houses, and also in larger scale such as Gozan Okuribi (Bonfire Events on Five Mountains) in Kyoto.
As for okuribi, it is still observed today at the entrance or in the garden of some houses, and also in larger scale such as Gozan Okuribi (Bonfire Events on Five Mountains) in Kyoto.

sen.j: が、村落あげての大がかりな迎え火であるこの御招霊の慣習は高度経済成長と言われた昭和40年代中頃までで終えている場合が多い。
sen.e: On the other hand, the tradition of oshorei as a big mukaebi event for the whole village had been lost in many regions by around 1970, the period of high economic growth.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: On the other hand, the tradition of oshorei as a big mukaebi event for the whole village had been lost in many regions by around 1970, during a period of high economic growth.
On the other hand, the tradition of oshorei as a big mukaebi event for the whole village had been lost in many regions by around 1970, during a period of high economic growth.

sen.j: このことは予期せぬ野火に至る恐れがあったり、農家の減少で藁が十分に集められない、若者がサラリーマン化して日程の都合がつかないな、ダムの建設で山間部を離れる、過疎化や近代化など多くの古来からのそれぞれの地域の慣習や行事が消えて行く事と共通するものがある。
sen.e: The reasons for this also have caused many other time-honored customs or events to disappear: concern about unexpected bush fire, lack of straw caused by a decrease in the farming population, changing life style of young men who are busy as office workers, construction of dams which drives villagers out of mountainous regions, or depopulation and modernization.
sen.cmt: 原文「つかないな」の最後の「な」は入力まちがいかと思われます。
sen.e: The reasons for this, which have also caused many other time-honored customs and events to disappear, include: concern about unexpected brush fire, lack of straw caused by a decrease in the farming population, changing life style of young men who are busy as office workers, construction of dams which drive villagers out of mountainous regions, depopulation and modernization.

The reasons for this, which have also caused many other time-honored customs and events to disappear, include: concern about unexpected bush fire, lack of straw caused by a decrease in the farming population, changing life style of young men who are busy as office workers, construction of dams which drive villagers out of mountainous regions, depopulation and modernization.

sen.j: また、死者の霊そのものを「おしょらい」や「おしょらいさま」と呼び、「御招霊」とは違う漢字の表記の「お精霊」や「お精霊様」とする迎え火や送り火も京都のほか多くの地域で広く行われる。
sen.e: Different mukaebi or okuribi practices from '御招霊' are taken place in Kyoto and many other regions in which they call the soul of the deceased itself 'oshorai' or 'oshorai sama' using the different kanji (Chinese characters): 'お精霊' or 'お精霊さま'.

Different mukaebi or okuribi practices from '御招霊' take place in Kyoto and many other regions in which they call the soul of the deceased itself 'oshorai' or 'oshorai sama' using the different kanji (Chinese characters): 'お精霊' or 'お精霊さま'.

Different mukaebi or okuribi practices from '御招霊' take place in Kyoto and many other regions in which they call the soul of the deceased itself 'oshorai' or 'oshorai sama' using the different kanji (Chinese characters): 'お精霊' or 'お精霊さま.'
sen.cmt: ピリオドの位置を移動しました。

sen.j: 北陸地方（浄土真宗の信者が多いとされる）
sen.e: Hokuriku District (with many believers of Jodo Shinshu: the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism)
Hokuriku District (with many believers of Jodo Shinshu: the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism)
Hokuriku district (with many believers of Jodo Shinshu: the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism)
sen.cmt: district 小文字に変更しました。

sen.j: 富山県
sen.e: Toyama Prefecture
Toyama Prefecture
Toyama Prefecture

sen.j: 中新川郡上市町
sen.e: Kamiichi Machi, Nakaniikawa Gun
Kamiichi Machi, Nakaniikawa Gun
Kamiichi-machi, Nakaniikawa-gun

sen.j: 高岡市金屋町 (高岡市)など
sen.e: Kanaya Machi, Takaoka City
sen.cmt: 原文の（高岡市）はリンク先のようですので、訳出しませんでした。
sen.e: Kanaya Machi, Takaoka City
Kanaya-machi (Takaoka City), Takaoka City
sen.cmt: 括弧内の(高岡市）も追加しました。

sen.j: 石川県
sen.e: Ishikawa Prefecture
Ishikawa Prefecture
Ishikawa Prefecture

sen.j: 志賀町など
sen.e: Shiga cho
Shiga cho
Shiga-cho

sen.j: 能美市（旧辰口町）山間部など
sen.e: Mountainous region of Nomi City (Old Tatsunokuchi Machi)
Mountainous region of Nomi City (Old Tatsunokuchi Machi)
Mountainous region of Nomi City (Old Tatsunokuchi-machi)
sen.cmt: 地名表記を統一しました。

sen.j: 加賀市山中温泉、栢野大杉がある栢野など。
sen.e: Yamanaka-onsen Hot Spring, and Kayano known for the Great Sugi (cedar) of Kayano, Kaga City
Yamanaka-onsen Hot Spring, and Kayano known for the Great Sugi (cedar) of Kayano, Kaga City
Yamanaka-onsen Hot Spring, and Kayano known for the Great Sugi (cedar) of Kayano, Kaga City

sen.j: 福井県
sen.e: Fukui Prefecture
Fukui Prefecture
Fukui Prefecture

sen.j: 勝山市猪野口など
sen.e: Inokuchi, Katsuyama City
Inokuchi, Katsuyama City
Inokuchi, Katsuyama City

sen.j: 秋田県
sen.e: Akita Prefecture
Akita Prefecture
Akita Prefecture

sen.j: にかほ市象潟町の「盆小屋行事」「来とうね」
sen.e: Bon goya gyoji' (an event at a hut in the Bon season) 'Kitone' in Kisakata Machi, Nikaho City
sen.cmt: 文頭の「'」は表示上消えてしまうため、２回続けて入力してあります。
sen.e: Bon goya gyoji' (an event at a hut in the Bon season) 'Kitone' in Kisakata Machi, Nikaho City
The 'Bon goya gyoji' (an event at a hut in the Bon season) 'Kitone' (a call made to the deceased, meaning "Please come back") in Kisakata-machi, Nikaho City:
sen.cmt: 翻訳を補足しました。コロンを追加しました。

sen.j: - 2008年3月、国の記録選択無形民俗文化財
sen.e: -March 2008 Nation's selected intangible properties of folk culture
sen.cmt: 原文の「民族文化財選択無形民俗文化財」は単語の重複がありますので、Wikipediaで検索した「国の記録選択無形民俗文化財」に原文修正し訳出しました。「-」から始めると数式と認識されるため、文頭に「'」を追加しました。
sen.e: -March 2008 Nation's selected intangible properties of folk culture
Registered as nation's selected intangible properties of folk culture in March 2008
